misconceptions.name: Implemented average acceleration problem instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program computes average acceleration from initial and final velocities and time, and prints a physics-related message, instead of summing the even numbers among five integer inputs as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the assignment is to read v0, v1, and t and print the average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read 5 integers from the user, filter out the even ones using an evenness test (e.g., n % 2 == 0), accumulate their sum, and then print "Sum of even numbers: <sum>".
symptoms: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t instead of a sum
Output label is "The average acceleration is" instead of "Sum of even numbers:"
No accumulator variable for a running sum of even integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignments or reuse of a template solution for an average acceleration problem without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the algorithm specifically for summing even numbers: use a loop to read 5 integers, check each with n % 2 == 0, accumulate only the even ones, and then print the sum with the required label.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure and naming (v0, v1, t, averageAcceleration) match a standard acceleration exercise and do not reference sums or even numbers at all.

evidence.note: Main method reads v0, v1, t and prints an average acceleration result instead of summing even numbers.
Helper method implements the physics formula (v1 - v0) / t, confirming the program solves a different problem.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles with a physics-specific prompt instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts the user for three values (v0, v1, and t) and reads them as doubles, instead of reading five integers as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the input should consist of three numeric values representing v0, v1, and t, read as doubles.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integer values from the user, typically using Scanner.nextInt(), and not assume physics-specific variables or a different number of inputs.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for v0, v1, and t
Only three values are read from input
Scanner.nextDouble() is used instead of Scanner.nextInt() for integer input
No mechanism to read exactly five integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copied an input pattern from another exercise that used three double values and did not adapt it to the new requirement of reading five integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt to something like "Enter 5 integers:" and use a loop with input.nextInt() to read five integer values from the user.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Input-related names and prompt explicitly target v0, v1, and t, and only three doubles are read, which is incompatible with the requirement to read five integers.

evidence.note: Three inputs are read (v0, v1, t) as doubles, with a physics-specific prompt; no reading of five integers.
Helper method is hard-coded to read a single double, reinforcing the three-double-input pattern.

misconceptions.name: No conditional or modulus check to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0) and does not use any conditional logic to filter values before contributing to a result.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving the task only requires computing a direct formula from the three inputs, with no need for conditional checks or filtering.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only the even numbers, the program must test each input value with a condition like if (n % 2 == 0) before adding it to the sum, so that odd numbers are excluded.
symptoms: No if statements or conditional logic related to parity
No use of the modulus operator (%) to test evenness
Result depends only on the formula (v1 - v0) / t, not on any selection among inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a direct formula-based computation instead of recognizing the need to selectively include only even numbers via conditional tests.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an integer variable for each input in a loop and use an if (n % 2 == 0) check before adding n to the running sum, so that only even numbers contribute.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program lacks any conditionals or modulus usage; combined with the wrong problem implementation, this indicates the even-number filtering logic was not attempted.

evidence.note: Main method contains no if statements or % operator; all computation is a single formula with no conditional filtering.

misconceptions.name: No loop or structure to handle multiple required inputs
misconceptions.description: The code does not use any loop to iterate over multiple inputs; it only reads three values once. For the specified task (processing 5 integers), a loop is the natural and expected structure to handle repeated input and processing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student treats the problem as a single-step formula computation where looping over multiple values is unnecessary.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Because the program must process 5 integers, it should either use a loop (for/while) to read and process each integer in turn, or at least explicitly handle five separate inputs. A loop is the standard, scalable approach.
symptoms: main method contains no for or while loops
Inputs are read only once each (three values total)
No index or iteration variable to traverse multiple inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student copied a single-calculation example and did not translate the idea of '5 integers' into a repeated processing pattern using loops.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a loop (e.g., for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)) that reads one integer per iteration and processes it. This ensures the code matches the requirement to handle 5 inputs and scales naturally to more values.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of any loop in a problem that explicitly involves handling multiple values strongly indicates a missing understanding of the need for looping in this context.

evidence.note: Entire main method performs a single calculation with three inputs and contains no loop construct to process multiple (5) inputs.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program does not contain any conditional checks (such as using n % 2 == 0) to determine whether an input is even. It simply computes (v1 - v0) / t, unrelated to even-number filtering.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the computation is purely arithmetic on three doubles and does not require any decision-making based on input parity.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, each of the 5 integers must be checked with a conditional expression (e.g., if (n % 2 == 0)) to decide whether it should be included in the sum. Odd numbers should be ignored in the accumulation.
symptoms: No if-statements or boolean conditions in the entire program
No use of the modulus operator (%)
Computation depends only on v0, v1, t via a fixed formula
misconceptions.root_cause: The student focused on reproducing a formula-based example and did not translate the specification's requirement of 'only the even numbers' into conditional logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, use an if-statement to check if it is even (n % 2 == 0). Only add values that satisfy this condition to the running sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No conditional constructs or modulus operator appear anywhere in the code, even though they are central to the stated problem of summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Main method performs only arithmetic and printing; there are no if-statements or use of % to distinguish even from odd numbers.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The naming, formula, and printed message all consistently reflect an average-acceleration computation, not any form of sum of even integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Loop Structure for Multiple Inputs
misconceptions.description: Student does not use a loop to read the 5 integers. Instead, there are only 3 hardcoded individual read statements.

No for loop or while loop

misconceptions.name: Missing Even/Odd Detection Logic
misconceptions.description: Student's code contains no conditional check to determine if a number is even. The core filtering logic is completely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may not understand how to test for evenness, or did not attempt to implement this requirement because they were solving a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To check if a number is even, use the modulo operator: 'if (number % 2 == 0)'. If the remainder when dividing by 2 is 0, the number is even.
symptoms: No 'if' statement checking for even numbers
No use of modulo operator (%)
No filtering/selection of even numbers
All numbers (if any were read) would be processed the same way
misconceptions.root_cause: Student implemented a completely different algorithm (average acceleration) instead of the sum-of-evens logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a conditional: 'if (number % 2 == 0) { sum += number; }' inside your input loop to accumulate only even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is a core requirement of the problem, and it is completely absent from the student's code. The code calculates acceleration instead, showing no attempt at the required algorithm.

evidence.note: This is the only computation in the code. It calculates (v1-v0)/t and contains no modulo operator, no even/odd check, no conditional logic.

evidence.note: Rubric explicitly lists this as a requirement worth 1 point, but student code has no such check.
